11:06 am
PM11:06am

In full, for non-subscribers

BE11:06am

................................ Okay.

PM11:06am

THE former boss of Rolls-Royce's aero-engine arm is being lined up as the new chief executive of Meggitt amid speculation over a takeover of the aircraft parts maker.

Tony Wood was last week named chief operating officer of the FTSE 250 company, whose parts range from brakes for jumbo jets to cooling gear for F-16 fighter planes.

Sources said Meggitt is likely to trigger a hunt for a replacement for the current chief executive, Stephen Young, within a year and Wood is in pole position for the role.

His appointment as chief operating officer came as Elliott Management, the activist US investor run by hedge fund titan Paul Singer, turned up the heat on Meggitt.

City sources said potential predators including US industrial behemoth Honeywell are being courted over a takeover of the £3.5bn company. They added that the French aerospace giant Safran and British car and plane parts maker GKN are also potential buyers.

Wall Street raider Elliott, which took a 5.2% stake in Meggitt in August, is understood to be keen on a bid or break-up offer. It has been in touch with some of Meggitt's biggest shareholders in recent weeks, sources said.

Meggitt is chaired by Sir Nigel Rudd, who presided over the sale of British stalwarts including Boots and glassmaker Pilkington.

It has long been seen as vulnerable to a takeover. A profit warning a year ago sent its shares plunging by a fifth, forcing it to launch a restructuring and redundancy drive. Two of its biggest customers, the aircraft makers Airbus and Boeing, want suppliers to consolidate as the industry's stellar growth shows signs of slowing and they try to squeeze more profit from their supply chains.

Wood was one of the highest-profile casualties of Rolls-Royce's recent woes, when he left at the start of this year after 15 years with the engineer.

Meggitt's shares ended last week at 448.6p and have risen by almost 20% this year.

Meggitt and Elliott declined to comment.

11:07 am
PM11:07am

And then the follow up in the Times on Monday...

PM11:07am

The chairman of Meggitt tried yesterday to quieten City chatter about a takeover of the aircraft parts maker as he and his wife bought shares in the company.

Speculation on trading floors had resurfaced in recent sessions and the shares flew higher after weekend reports named Honeywell, the American conglomerate, Safran, the French aerospace group, and GKN, the components maker, as potential predators. The rumours were stoked way back in August when Elliott Management, the American activist investor, took a 5.2 per cent stake and began contacting other big shareholders.

City traders described the suggestions as "noise" yesterday follow on for @ shortly before Meggitt issued a trading update to the stock market in mid-afternoon dealings. The £3.5 billion company said that Sir Nigel Rudd and Lady Rudd together had bought 2,500 shares worth about £11,300. One dealer at a mid-cap broker said that the share purchase indicated there was no M&A in the offing. In choppy dealings, shares in Meggitt closed up 6¼p at 454¾p, off its high for the day.

11:33 am

(Sos, Sancerre, actually)

BE11:33am

Have .... I dunno ... Natixis?

BE11:34am

Just as Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond is about to present to Parliament the government’s revised growth and fiscal deficit forecasts and announce eventual measures to stimulated the economy, there was a pleasant surprise in that public sector net borrowing (PSNB) was lower than expected in October (£4.3bn compared with an expected £6bn). This was due notably to tax receipts (especially corporation tax) being higher than anticipated, as a result of which it can be hoped that the deficit for the current tax year will overshoot the OBR forecast by “only” £11bn, assuming of course that economic activity does not cave in before next April.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

This pleasant surprise owes much to the fact that, so far, most macroeconomic indicators are still on green: decent GDP growth was recorded in Q3 (+2.3%), households are not in the least ruffled by the erosion in their purchasing power (retail sales soared by almost 8% year-on-year last month), the PMI are all comfortably above 50, and the unemployment has improved to 4.8% (near its pre-crisis lows). Admittedly, for many observers, the slowdown in the economy has yet to kick in: the good data out of the labour market has come at the cost of more precarious conditions (zero-hours contracts nearing one million mark, rise in the number of self-employed, once again on an uptrend and now exceeding 4.5 million), while the sharp decline in investment decisions will end up depressing investment and denting economic growth sooner or later (the two cycles being very closely correlated). Also, inflation is set to rise further, which will crimp household purchasing power.

BE11:35am

Philip Hammond does not seem to be blinded by the apparent resilience of the British economy, having mentioned several times the risk of a slowdown in activity linked to Brexit. It is likely that the growth forecast for next year due to be announced today will have undergone a downward revision. According to certain estimates, the cumulative additional deficit over the next 5 years (which could be seen as linked to Brexit) could reach £100bn, which is considerable and would in theory reduce the government’s leeway to “readjust” the budget.
In this context, what could the Chancellor of the Exchequer propose? It has already been made clear that the government is no longer looking to balance the books by the end of the decade. There are rumours that any objective set by the government would concern the primary deficit as opposed to the overall deficit. Even assuming the government lower its sights as regards balancing the budget, it will have limited leeway. Since last August, the 10-year Gilt has been underperforming its German counterpart, over which period the Gilt-Bund spread has shot up from 60bp to 114bp. This spread is not much tighter than the Bono-Bund spread, even though the UK’s credit (AA at S&P) is better than Spain’s (BBB+). This widening of the 10-year Gilt-Bund spread is explained for 70% by the faster rise in the inflation premium priced into Gilts and for 30% by the faster rise in the real rate. This sharp widening is surprising in several respect:
1. Shortly after the announcement of the referendum results, the Bank of England revived the AFP and cut the bank rate. At the time, it hinted it would tolerate a temporary spike in inflation above its official target.
2. British debt is held mainly by resident investors (non-resident investors holding just 25%). It is therefore less exposed to the behaviour of non-resident investors than most other European debts.

PM11:35am

Here's some Credit Suisse as well

11:35 am
PM11:35am

Which my autumn statement filter didnt catch

PM11:35am

In this note, we lay out our expectations for the Autumn Statement on November 23. The Autumn Statement may mark the shift from a “tight fiscal policy/loose monetary policy” to a "loose fiscal policy/tight monetary policy" regime in the UK.

We expect the Treasury to announce a new set of fiscal rules. The substantial tightening of fiscal policy set out in the March budget looks inappropriate and unachievable in the current environment. We expect the Treasury to reset fiscal policy, scrapping the previous budget's target of reaching a surplus by 2019/20 and aiming to achieve a balanced budget in the next parliament.

It is widely expected that the Chancellor will adopt a new flexible fiscal framework. Instead of having rigid deficit targets, which the government has failed to meet in the past, the Treasury is likely to be flexible and allow the headroom for additional stimulus if growth is hit by the Brexit vote. Thus there is likely to be room for the deficit to rise if the growth data warrant it.

One way it could attain this is by targeting a balance in the current budget rather than a surplus in the overall balance, similar to Gordon Brown’s Golden rule. This rule would be flexible enough to allow for an increase in gross investment spending with an aim of balancing the current budget in the near term.

In our view a big discretionary fiscal stimulus package is unlikely. We do, however, expect a modest discretionary expansion program comprising of an increase in infrastructure spending of a few billions pounds a year (probably £5bn). We also expect some policies on housing to address the issue of supply shortages.

The fiscal deficit should increase even without any policy change, as the OBR is likely to project a weaker growth outlook and higher inflation compared to March. In 2016/17 automatic stabilizers have already started to kick in and given the deficit outturns so far, the Treasury would miss its deficit target in 2016/17. The deficit is expected to fall from £76.0bn in 2015/16 to £65.5bn in 2016/17, £10bn higher than the £55.5bn projected in the March budget.

The DMO is also going to publish its revised FY2016/17 gilt remit. We expect a £21.2bn rise in gilt sales in 2016/17, increasing total sales to £150.6bn and no changes to the T-bill programme.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

BE11:39am

Though still possible.

BE11:39am

We note management's comments around the complexity of a turnaround at Brammer, how long it may take and the execution risk (and other wider issues), and although we do not expect a counter-bid, we suspect other potential predators will be looking at Brammer.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Strategic Review. We read with interest the comments from Brammer's management with respect to the operational issues that need to be addressed at Brammer following a series of profit warnings, and a significant increase in the group's debt burden (which has ballooned since the half-year). Management outline that the potential turnaround of the group would be:

Complex
Require significant structural & behavioural changes
Incur significant cash reorganisation costs
Would take at least three years to implement
Carry significant execution risk and uncertainty
A likely equity raise (which Brammer has been considering) has risen to at least £130m and this is also dependent upon Brammer securing appropriate covenant amendments and medium-term debt facilities
A revised 'go-to-market' strategy is needed
Efficiency improvements are needed across the board
Equally, Brammer's management believes that Advent brings a lot to the table.

BE11:39am

Other parties likely to be interested? Despite this being an recommended offer, we would not rule out other parties looking at Brammer, and a counter-bid should not be ruled out - it is unlikely, however, in our view. As outlined above, there are many risks attached to this takeover, and it appears to be a very big job, but Brammer offers an opportunity for overseas buyers to take a position in the EU Industrial MRO distribution market.

BE11:39am

See? As I say, it's an old fashioned distressed company rescue.

CMC Markets PLC (CMCX:LSE): Last: 195.90, down 7.2 (-3.55%), High: 201.00, Low: 190.80, Volume: 159.98k

BE11:41am

11:41 am

PM11:42am

11:42 am
BE11:42am

That's a fair question. I don't know. Lots of talk in the statement about subdued market conditions, which doesn't seem to be a problem for peers.

BE11:43am

Shore incoming.

BE11:43am

CMC has this morning reported interim results for the six months to 30th September. Having warned at the time of its AGM on 7th Sep (and re-confirmed in a trading statement on 29th Sep), that net operating income (revenue) was expected to be down year-on year (yoy), the results show a decline of 4% to £75.5m for the period. This translates into a steep yoy fall in EBITDA down 27% to £21.9m (margin down 9ppts yoy to 29%), with underlying PBT down 29% at £18.8m and underlying eps down 29% at 5.1p. An interim dividend of 2.98p, was declared (33% of the prior year dividend) albeit the company’s policy of paying out 50% of earnings will imply a cut in the full year dividend from last year’s 9.83p unless management choose to regard the current year as exceptional in the context of a five year plan to grow net operating income to £220m by y/e Mar 2020. Overall the profit fall (costs up 9% in a period where revenue was down 4%) will make it difficult for CMC to achieve our current full year PBT forecast of £58.7m, especially as current trading is simply described as having seen ‘no further easing’ and we would expect to be downgrading by c10%, subject to any further detail at the 11am results presentation.

Growth in active clients was up 8% yoy at 47,623 indicating a further slowdown in the month of September (this metric had been +13% after 3m to 30th June and up 9% for the 5m to 31st Aug). However, lower volatility meant that clients traded less with average revenue per client down 13% to £1488 with Europe picked out as being particularly weak. An update on regulation also flags potential restrictions on digital marketing in Europe and wider conduct issues (from unregulated foreign exchange and binary operators) attracting negative media attention. We see CMC operating very much at the quality end of the regulated markets.

The statement flags that if there is no improvement in client trading levels in H2 (and we would remind investors that the company will lap a very strong comparative in Jan/Feb where markets had been very volatile in 2016) then full year net operating income may be below last year’s level which was £169.4m (we currently forecast £171.3m). However, our current full year EBITDA margin assumption of 38.4% (versus 40.9% last year) now looks very challenging.

At last night’s closing price of 203p and before any change to forecasts (provisionally down c10%), CMC trades on 12.5x our Mar ’17 adjusted eps of 16.2p, falling to 10.6x in Mar ’18 (19.2p) and a prospective Mar ’17 dividend yield of 4.4% (9.0p). These metrics represent a material discount to closest peer IG Group (IGG, Sell at 837p), currently trading on 17.5x our May ’17 adjusted eps. We believe IG’s longer track record and stronger recent execution merits a premium. Our last published fair value for CMC was 240p, based on 13.5x 12m forward adjusted eps (a 10% discount to our IG fair value multiple). While this theoretically represented sufficient upside to consider moving to a more positive recommendation, the proximity of the profit warning to February’s 240p IPO (and the fact that even our low end numbers needed a decent H2) meant we thought the company may have to spend a period in the ‘sin bin’ as confidence with investors is rebuilt. Based on this morning’s results and likely downgrades we expect to be reducing our fair value (and increasing the discount to IG) to somewhere closer to 200p. HOLD

11:43 am
PM11:44am

Kinda sums it up

BE11:44am

And Numis.

BE11:44am

Total operating income declined 4% to £76m in H117 (-3% vs. NSe: £78m) while adj. PBT declined 29% to £19m (-10% vs. NSe: £21m). As previously warned, this was primarily driven by a sharp reduction in revenues per client (-13%) and higher management LTIP costs post-IPO (FY2017E: £6m). The Group has seen no further easing of client trading so far in H217 and, with income historically weighted to H2, expects to deliver an improvement on H117. However, management did caution that if subdued conditions persist and client trading does not improve, then net operating income is likely to be moderately lower than FY2016 (we currently assume 2% growth). We have placed our recommendation Under Review as we look to downgrade our forecasts to reflect the weaker interim results, management’s more cautious outlook (surprising given the ongoing political uncertainty) and the changing regulatory environment in Europe

Hunting PLC (HTG:LSE): Last: 539.50, up 32 (+6.31%), High: 554.50, Low: 517.00, Volume: 341.90k
11:47 am
BE11:47am

Already had a big rally on the recovery of the North American shale industry .....

BE11:48am

Closest correlation we have over here with the weekly Baker Hughes rig count data, I think.

BE11:48am

Anyway, Credit Suisse saying more to come.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

Upgrade to Outperform. With greater exposure to well completions (mostly because of Titan) and US unconventionals, HTG should have more operational leverage to this recovery cycle than 2009. The recent improvement in orders suggests customers have consumed excess inventories of certain product lines. Rig count (up more than 50% from the bottom across major basins) and DUC completion trends add substance to this thesis, while a Trump Administration should also be a boon to the US Oil & Gas Industry. All this suggests a brighter outlook for HTG.

BE11:49am

Patience required. Many HTG customers may need to fill their own plants / facilities before sourcing product from HTG. The competitive environment has intensified recently, while burning through higher-cost inventory may also hamper margin expansion initially in the recovery phase. HTG’s business outside NAM may also be a drag through 2017, notably offshore markets in the North Sea and Asia Pacific. One should therefore expect HTG’s recovery to lag that of its mainstream customer base.

PM11:49am

(roddy -- what is this? Link?)

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Strengthened balance sheet: HTG had made solid progress reducing net working capital and net debt through the downturn. The successful placing in late October raised over GBP70m (~USD87.5m) of gross proceeds, which effectively eliminates group net debt. This enables HTG to better respond to growing business development opportunities while providing even greater headroom to banking covenants. It also removes a barrier to HTG potentially participating in industry consolidation.

BE11:50am

Valuation: We increase 2017/18E revenues / EBITDA by 2%/2% and 4%/8% respectively, although the EPS impact is muted by the placing. Putting our forecasts in context, 2018E EBITDA is ~60% below the 2014 peak, but we are 15% above the street, and see an EV/EBITDA multiple of 8x, which is materially below peers in the 9-14x range. We utilise higher peer group multiples in our SOTP valuation, and, in aggregate, this drives an increase in TP to GBp575p (from GBp500).

BE11:56am

We currently model $1.5B in peak sales for SMA, at 50% probability to account for competition from gene therapy. Add’l $1.5B is $37/share to DCF. We assume $300K price; every $50K more is $6/share to DCF. 2017 consensus is ~$100M in 2017. Every $50M in sales in ’17 adds 17c to EPS. We model a launch over 5 years reaching ~11K patients on drug at peak. If launch is more like CF because population is diagnosed and uptake is brisk, ramp could be faster. Biogen has said there are 20k eligible in US/EU/Japan.

BE12:00pm

Our view: While still early days for the combined entity, the new Vectura benefits from a broader product portfolio, combined pipeline and the prospects of becoming an altogether more significant operator in the respiratory market. This has been reflected in a strong H1 result with good revenue growth combined with cost synergies confirmed at £10m per year by 2018. From a pipeline perspective, the timing of a substitutable generic Advair in the US is key and we would highlight PIII results for VR475 move closer with a readout in 2018 while the development of five inhaled generic inhaled products progresses.

· Results demonstrate the additive benefits of merger – Having provided a trading update in early September todays results offer little by way of surprise. Pro-forma revenue and EBITDA growth was 31% and 63% respectively (£89.5m and £30.8m respectively) with reported revenues and EBITDA of £73.9m and £30.8m respectively. For the branded respiratory portfolio, we suspect that Ultibro in particular will have benefited from the positive implications of the FLAME study. Flutiform continues to benefit from geographical availability (ex US) with 35% growth compared to the prior period. Cash position at the end of the period was £92m.

· Recent GOLD guidelines helpful but we await fate of Utibron in the US – The recently updated GOLD COPD guidelines are clearly a plus for those operating in the respiratory market with LAMA/LABAs taking centre stage as anticipated. However the US remains an important territory and we continue to wait for Vectura’s development partner Novartis to decide the fate of Ultibron here: Apparently waiting for the results of a head to head study with Anoro and already having received FDA approval over a year ago, albeit as a twice daily product versus GSK’s once daily Anoro. Partner Novartis could yet further cement its excellent European competitive position with a potential first to market fixed triple although it lags GSK substantially in the US.

· Skye acquisition a positive – The merger of Vectura and SkyePharma should help broaden the respiratory offering, participating in the major respiratory classes and place the enlarged entity in a stronger position to forge more deals and ultimately build its own sales and marketing infrastructure. We like the hybrid business model followed by Vectura and the security that royalty revenues bring but believe that the main focus should be to continue to build on the prospects for self-commercialisation as management seeks to build a respiratory powerhouse in what is a highly competitive market segment. The addition of a cash generative Flutiform based business should enable the company to acquire additional assets and realise its ambitions more easily.

· Valuation – We believe that Vectura is in an enviable position with a growing cash pile, a proprietary pipeline moving forward and the opportunity to participate in the generic Advair opportunity in the US. Despite its recent move into profitability, we believe that a DCF is the best way to value the future optionality in the Vectura pipeline. Employing a WACC of 8.5%, our DCF generates an NPV of 160p, roughly in line with the current share price. We maintain our HOLD recommendation.

· Risks – Risks to the Vectura investment case include partnering risk in that it relies on the success of its commercial partners to generate royalty income. Pipeline risk is also present with acquisitions taking it into the domain of own product development and away from a dependency on it partner’s efforts. While we believe that these programmes are at the lower risk end of the spectrum, they are still at a relatively early stage and there is the risk that they do not meet regulatory requirements.

Vectura Group PLC (VEC:LSE): Last: 149.80, up 3.5 (+2.39%), High: 153.00, Low: 147.60, Volume: 1.57m
